name: Parth Kochhar
comment info:
Watch out, Football Fans!

	This graph showcases a heavy left-skewed bimodal distribution between the percentage of football players diagnosed with chronic traumatic encephalopathy and the severity of injuries experienced within their respective football careers. There is an increased risk of chronic traumatic encephalopathy becoming more severe and even fatal as head injuries increase due to progressive disease symptoms.
	The graph showcases that football players are significantly more likely to develop chronic traumatic encephalopathy at more severe stages based on an increased cumulative injury force. With only 1696 football players in the NFL and this study utilizing 631 players, we know there is no sample size or speculation issue. 
	I wonder why the graph showcases around 35% of players with no chronic traumatic encephalopathy near the right end of the chart. It is an exact outlier compared to the rest of the data and completely ignores the established increasing trend. 
	Considering that my neighborhood is extremely close-knit and full of children who play basketball professionally, looking into the long-term effects of drastic injuries during the sport should be considered.

replies.comment info:
Good afternoon, @Parth Kochhar --

Great noticings and wonderings.  

The "No C.T.E." in the second to last segmented bar graph is unexpected.  You can review the original study "Leveraging football accelerometer data to quantify associations between repetitive head impacts and chronic traumatic encephalopathy in males."  Maybe there you will find an explanation.

name: Isabella P. AOSE
comment info:
This graph shows the cumulative force of head hits for 631 former football players and how that affected their  CTE. From this graph, I observe that more cumulative force usually creates greater head trauma, and less curative force results in less head trauma. CTE or chronic traumatic encephalopathy is associated with repeated blows to the head. Therefore it can be assumed that the more traumatic these hits are the more damage they will cause. I wonder if there is a direct correlation between the severity of the disease in the symptoms of memory loss, depression, aggressive behavior, and, sometimes, suicidal thoughts. This graph further demonstrates how unpredictable CTE can be at times. For example, if someone is hit with middle-level cumulative force they could have anywhere from no CTE at all to extremely severe stage 4 CTE. This could be a seriously life-changing difference for someone. However, there is a clear trend within the graph that directly relates more force with a greater CTE and less force with minor or no CTE. I really hope that this graph reaches the right audience and spreads awareness of contact sports such as football and boxing where head injuries are common. I also hope that this leaves an impact on people so much so that there become more regulations and/or head protective gear in these sports to try and prevent severe CTE for players, especially teens who will suffer the long-term effects.
“Watch Out Head Trauma Coming Your Way!”

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Isabella P. AOSE --

Great noticings.  A couple comments relating to the statistics in this graph:

The study of the 631 brains specifically found an association between CTE and cumulative force (which includes subconcussions), not CTE and hits.  This is a major finding and extends the likelihood of CTE.  The Reveal gives the link to the study so you can read about this difference.

Statisticians avoid the use of the word "cause" in relationships of variables unless there is an experiment.  In this case, we say there is an "association."  Take a look at the Reveal which explains this in more depth.

I hope you can share these comments with your classmates.  Hope to "see" you for the Spelling Bee graph in two weeks.

I wonder if there are factors beyond cumulative force that also influence CTE onset such as genetics, individual resilience, or protective equipment that may influence CTE susceptibility.

The graph underlines the crucial relationship between cumulative head force and the prevalence of CTE, indicating that experiencing higher cumulative head force leads to higher percentage of players reporting later stages of CTE. 

As a high school student in New Jersey and given the prevalence of football culture within the northeast region of the United States, it is important to stay informed and up to date with these statistics because it can empower athletes, parents, coaches, and communities to make informed decisions regarding participation in the sport and advocate for safety measures. 

Headline: Exploring the Complex Link between Football Head Hits and CTE Risk

name: Katherine H
comment info:
This graph depicts how head injuries have gravely impacted football players, specifically regarding chronic traumatic encephalopathy. Chronic traumatic encephalopathy, C.T.E. for short, a brain disease that can result from repeated trauma to the head, is currently both incurable and fatal. According to this graph, the more head trauma a football player experiences, the more likely they are to suffer from C.T.E. While C.T.E. can cause illnesses such as dementia, it has also been deteriorating mental health. Former players, Junior Seau, Philip Adams, and Dave Duerson, all diagnosed with severe depression from C.T.E., took their own lives. Aaron Hernandez and Jovan Belcher, both players suffering from C.T.E., were described as growing violent before commiting murder. I wonder why C.T.E., being such a pressing issue, is it not being discussed and researched more. Though this graph correlates brain injuries in football to chronic traumatic encephalopathy, this disease can be brought about by any high-contact sport. In my community, most people play or have played an intensive sport where concussions are prevalent. I have witnessed athletes be rushed to the hospital after serious head blows in sports ranging from soccer to cheerleading. As athletes in all sports continue to push the limits harder each year, will I have to worry about my teenage friends developing a life-threatening brain disease?

“What Is More Important: Pigskin or Your Life?”

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Mrs. Afocx's Students --

Great job, Mrs. Afocx’s students in Virginia.  Let me address “Bell” by “Bell.”

Bells 2 and 4:  
Where do you see evidence that “One hundred percent of the players studied experienced stage 3 and stage 4 damage”? 
There are other sports in which players experience CTE, especially hockey.  

Bell 8:
“They noticed that less cumulative force resulted in fewer CTE.”  Absolutely!
They wondered if there was a particular unit used to determine cumulative force. Yes, it is measures by head impact count and acceleration across different levels and positions of football play.  
Why is there a random gap in the data? That is a great question.  I wondered this, too.  Is it because of the sample available, an error in recording or other reasons?
Why did the researcher choose 631 players? These were the players who had donated their brains for research. 
Headline: Is There A Better Way To Protect Athletes in High Contact Sports?  Think about what words should be in this headline that point to this particular graph.

name: Amelia AOSE
comment info: Football is a relatively dangerous sport, given how many players suffer from head injuries on average. A C.T.E., or Chronic traumatic encephalopathy, is a traumatic brain injury like a concussion. Football encourages players to tackle other players with extreme force to knock them down or remove obstacles. There is little control over how a person falls once they are hit, but how they are hit absolutely determines how badly they are injured. 100% of players who were hit with extreme force got a stage 4 C.T.E. upon impact on the ground. I notice how night numbers of players have received severe head trauma from the sport, but there is little education on how to prevent those injuries. Being hit with extreme force will lead to injury, but in the heat of the game, players are not actively thinking about injury prevention, only winning. I wonder why there is not more of an emphasis on safety in football. While players do wear padding, they are still praised for hard hits and tackles are a main part of the entertainment in TV coverage. It is upsetting to see how dangerous it is because of how popular the sport is for Americans both play and watch. With events like the Super Bowl, it is easy to forget how dangerous the game is for the players. We encourage good tackles and wild plays, but in reality, the safety of the players should be the most important part. The graph is showing the “Unmentioned dangers of Football” by exhibiting statistics of real injuries.
